# Second Comparison: Base R vs the Tidyverse

:::::::::::::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}

Base R is the native tools that R has to deal with data. The syntax is outdated and better tools are available to use. 

The syntax to work in Base R is very similar to native python syntax. The biggest downside is that _it's not possible to chain operations together_ like selecting columns and filtering data. You would to constantly assign and reassign variables which results in very messy and unreadable code. 

If you use this, I will turn in my grave. Please don't make your life more difficult, use the Tidyverse.

Base R is native to R; no additional installations are required. 

:::
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
The Tidyverse allows chainable actions like this: 
```{r}
#| eval: false
state_gdp <- data %>% 
    filter(
        population > 5000000 & 
        state %in% c("Washington", "Oregon", "California")
        )
    select(state, gdp, debt)
```

Run this code in the console to download the tidyverse

``` r
install.packages("tidyverse")
```

In order to be able to use this package, put this code at the top of your R Script or RMD file 

``` r 
library(tidyverse)
```
:::
::::::::::::::

<br>

<h3 align="center"> Selecting Columns </h3>

:::::::::::::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
###### Base R

`df$column_name`

`df[[]]`
:::

::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
###### Tidyverse

`df %>% select()`

```{r}
#| eval: false
df %>% select(column1, column2)
```
or 
```{r}
#| eval: false
select(df, column1, column2)
```
:::
::::::::::::::


<h3 align="center">Making New Columns</h3>

:::::::::::::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
<h6 align="center"; style="color:#808080"> Base R </h6>

<h6 align="center"> `df$profit <- df$revenue - df$cost` </h6>

:::
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
<h6 align="center"; style="color:#808080">Tidyverse</h6>

<h6 align="center"> `df %>% mutate(profit = revenue - cost)` </h6>

<h6 align="center"> or </h6>

<h6 align="center"> `mutate(df, profit = revenue - cost)` </h6>

:::
::::::::::::::

<h3 align="center"> Filtering Data </h3>

:::::::::::::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
Base R 

`df[df$temperature > 45]`
:::
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
Tidyverse

`df %>% filter(temperature > 45)`

or 

`filter(df, temperature > 45)`
:::
::::::::::::::


## Grouping & Summarising Data

:::::::::::::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
Base R 

I'm not sure how to do this yet...

:::
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
Tidyverse 

`df %>% group_by(city) %>% summarise(Avg_House_Price = mean(house_price))`

:::
::::::::::::::


### Sorting Data

:::::::::::::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
Base R

`mtcars[order(mpg, -cyl),]`
:::
::: {.column width=\"45%\"}
Tidyverse

`mtcars %>% arrange(mpg, desc(cyl))`

or 

`arrange(mtcars, mpg, desc(cyl))`
:::
::::::::::::::
